name: Andrew Black
comment info:
The regions with the greatest loss in bird population seem to follow a common pattern of the jet stream when cold arctic air dips down into the central plains area of US, especially during the winter. Presumably, global warming is warming this jet stream, which could have an impact on migration patterns, and, in turn, a negative impact on bird populations.

I’m so curious about why bird populations have faired so much better in the wetlands. Aren’t wetlands interspersed in all these regions, even the regions where bird populations were hardest hit? Perhaps, wetland birds are better adapted to changes in climate.

replies.name: B
replies.comment info: @Andrew Black I wonder if the wetlands have had some benefits from legislation that protects them, at the state and federal level, and consistent advocacy by groups like Ducks Unlimited.  I grew up in a time when wetlands were considered "wastelands" (e.g., the Meadowlands in NJ), but people started coming to their senses in the 1970s and 1980s and protections became law.

name: Katelyn M.
comment info:
1) Despite Canada appearing to be widely proactive in their fight against climate change, the decline in population of birds exists in their country as well. This means that their legislators are not keeping up with the impact of mass extinction as well. 

2) Legislators in both the US and Canada are likely not regulating the businesses that aiding in the decline. It is no secret that the American government, especially under more conservative administrations tends to institute policy that benefits businesses. Canada on the other hand, usually publicly decries the oil industry and other big businesses, yet Trudeau himself has had instances of issuing policy that protects oil and other industry. 

3) The loss of birds will likely impact other organisms and I question what impact this will have on climate, agriculture, and other species population rates.

name: Stephanie Rodas
comment info:
1.  I wonder what is causing such a huge decline in bird population. Upon doing some research, I found that the leading factors behind their decline are collisions with glass, pesticides, hunting by domestic cats, and by human hunters. This means that out of these 4 leading factors, 3 of the cause are inflicted by humans. Not only are humans contaminating the environment, but some are also killing birds as a sport. People should be more considerate of the repercussions of  their actions when it comes to these poor defenseless (against humans) animals.
2. What many people may also not consider is that the decline of bird population is also dangerous for plants. Due to their constant travel, birds serve as pollinators and they spread seeds. If birds go extinct, plants would struggle to reproduce in other areas and eventually a great majority of nature would die off. Considering that bees (which are also in danger) also help to pollinate and promote plant growth, there won't be as many options left for plants to disperse. 
3. I wonder if people consider that instead of using pesticide and destroying the habitats of birds, they could take car of the habitats and let nature take its course. Birds can get rid of insects that are considered pests; it's in their nature. So by aiding the conservation of these habits, they will promote a more natural pesticide: birds.

name: Krystal Mann
comment info:
1. When researching the topic of the decline of bird population, the main cause was due to the loss of habitats. Specifically because of deforestation birds are losing their homes at a rapid rate. Birds that reside in arid lands are losing their homes because of wildfires and as each species loses their homes their population drops and that ecosystem falls apart. I think its important to ember that not only is our planet being destroyed but the environment is crumbling because of it.Losing an ecosystem isn't a small accident it will affect everything  around it. So why aren't we doing anything about it?
2.Without birds many of the ecosystems you know and love will be gone. With birds declining the populations of insects will be at a new high, although that  won't be for long though as insects main source of food will become scarce. Other populations will have to find new sources of food which will throw off every ecosystem. 
3.What can we do? I think our best bet is to start a campaign that shows the effect of the loss of birds. The effect is significant and we as society should make sure to protect birds because the loss of birds will only add onto global warming and the environmental stress of today world. We need to protect our world for future generations to come and protecting these majestic creatures will be a step in the right direction.We as a society need to make a change and not changing will only allow for more animals to become endangered and maybe even extinct.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Krystal Mann I admire how much research you did and you have really opened my eyes on this topic. I strongly agree with the question why anyone isn't doing anything to help solve these issues with the bird population, and it is evident that the ecosystem will drastically change and possibly suffer without birds.

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: @Krystal Mann I do agree with your statement towards a campaign for birds. I would like to know more as to how this would be done, I suggest beginning with the pollution crisis. Also, although I do agree with bird's homes being destroyed causing them to leave, however; do you believe that that is the main reason for the migration, or could also include the seasonal temperature change and global warming?

HI, @Krystal Mann --

Thank you for your noticings and wonderings, as well as what you think we can do next to stop or curtail the decline in the bird population.  

You may want to search online for the “Migratory Bird Treaty Act” to learn about the nation’s oldest bird conservation law that protects nearly a thousand species of birds from poaching, hunting and from industrial activity.  Also, please return tomorrow when we publish the Reveal.  It includes the link to the article that has these graphs.  There you will read about some of the cause of the decline that you mention as well as other causes.

What action could you and your classmates take in your area to focus people’s attention to the bird population decline?

How about some catchy headlines from Rialto?

name: Morgan Hayes
comment info: In this graph, it shows that most birds live in grasslands while less in wetlands. The overall population has decreased but increased slightly in grasslands.  I wonder why the bird population is decreasing so much??

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Morgan Hayes  I agree with the adaptation of most birds which leaves one to wonder what is the reasoning behind the decline in the population. This might be for several reasons such as climate change which causes for birds to relocate to find new and better habitats or also because their current habitats are being converted for agricultural use which removes their nesting habitat.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Morgan Hayes I agree with how the bird population decreases and increases in certain areas which leads one to wonder what is the reasoning behind it. There are many factors that come into play that may lead for the population to decline such as climate change or natural disasters such as forest fires which cause birds to relocate to new habitats to build a better life but sometimes that isn’t guaranteed because of natural causes.

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: @Morgan Hayes I also noticed the different significance of the decrease of populations in specific areas of the region. I believe that climate change has a huge role with this huge loss of North American bird populations.Rising temperatures will ultimately destroy habitats from wildfires to heavy floods, destroying populations such as the bird.

name: Rose Fitzgerald
comment info:
I notice that while the wetlands have had a slight increase in bird population, every other biome, especially the grasslands, has lost a substantial portion of their bird population. 
What factors have led to the dramatic decrease in bird population? Why has the bird population in the wetlands increased while every other biome has experienced loss?

replies.name: K
replies.comment info: @Rose Fitzgerald I think the decrease of the bird population is due to the loss of their habitat because many companies are cutting down their homes and this prevents the species from repopulating. My question is why are birds that reside in the wetlands the only birds who are protected by law?

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Rose Fitzgerald  I think you made a great observation! I really liked that you noticed that when one biome increases, others decrease. I had the same question about what causes the bird population to decrease. It could be caused by natural disasters or man-made situations. The bird population may also be changing  because their biome is becoming less suitable to meet the needs of the birds.

name: Jolene King
